So my overall experience here wasn't all that bad..except for the food. It'll get the job done I guess...if you're drunk AF and have a craving for mediocre tacos. I guess I'll have to make my way to mission to satisfy my cravings!
author: Marie N.

description:
Not bad, but not really all the great either.  I got two taco.  Pollo Asada and Pollo Picante.

The Asada was pretty good.  The Picante was not very Picante at all and very sloppy.  It soaked the tortillas through in the time it took me to walk from the counter to a table in what is a small taqueria.

The real draw back is the swarming horde of middle schoolers that over ran the place right after I got in line.  There were seriously about 30 of them, and judging from the conversation behind me this is their daily lunch stop.

If you are looking for a quiet lunch I'd call ahead and find out when the inanely babbling wave teenies are going to hit.
author: Max Jonathan S.

description: I have been here a few times with friends. Their burritos are yummy here. I had their chicken and beef burritos, they let you choose your own fillings and dressings. I get very full from eating their burritos. They also have chips and nachos, but I never had it.
author: Serena Z.

description:
2 words:  spicy chicken.  

this place has been around for as long as i can remember...which would make it about 20-somethingish years, and they've always been good.  great food, very tasty, good portion sizes.
author: asia c.

description: This place has been a staple of mine ever since they moved from Gordo's as these were the chefs that worked there after their split about 15-20 years ago. Their portion sizes are ridiculous, always filling and a great value for the price. A super burrito with the mix of carnitas and grilled chicked is the perfect flavor for me as you get the savoriness of the pork and the grilled pepper & onion taste of the chicken. Mmmm. I actually want one right now!
author: Jared C.

description: Very friendly staff. If the order is wrong they replace it right away. Good quality burrito. Though they charge extra for chips its relatively cheap. A good place to go because simply pleasures is right next door, which has beer.
author: Alex C.

description:
I LOVE CHINOS !!!!!!

This place is amazing.  The food and staff are superb.  I used to live close and would come here 3-4 times a week.  The super burritos are addicting and the chile verde and carnitas are soooo good.  I moved out of SF and am so sad I can't come here much anymore.  I miss it!  If you haven't tried this place... trust me... its the best burrito place I've been to.
author: Meghann B.

description:
Listen, I am originally from San Diego, so when I moved to San Francisco, I set out to find the perfect burrito- just like home. Like many others who moved here from Southern California, the burritos just aren't the same. For a good burrito, it has to:

1) Be so soupy with so many beans it barely manages to stand up
2) The tortilla MUST be "springy" when bit into
3)Make me want another as soon as I finish
4) Be wrapped in PAPER none of this foil stuff.

Most of the burritos in the mission are good, but not quite "it." They have too much lettuce, the beans aren't right, or the tortilla is too dry/floury.  

Chino's has the best burritos in the city. As soon as i bit into my burrito It brought back the memories of San Diego Mexican food. Refried beans, cheese, guacamole and sour cream. The horchata is fresh and not grainy. And it cost me about 6 bucks, not bad.

Although I will forgive them for wrapping it in foil instead of paper.

PS: they don't use lard! But if you are vegetarian be careful- the rice has chicken stock in it.


edit: I guess this place depends on what day you come here, because when I came back the food REALLY needed salt, I guess I will still have to keep searching for the perfect burrito
author: Jenny U.

description:
The beef burritos here are really yummy, and cheap. 
It's never busy when I come by here, people are friendly, and it's walking distance from my house. 
Love it.

Perfect for munchies, Trust.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I went here over the wekkend, and I was supper happy. I came in with my baby, and ordered a super burrito, and was happy that they go step by step what you want in it, not like other taquerias i've been to where they take it to the back, and make it (and make it with mistakes!). What got me to do 5 stars is the service. As all my friends know, I HATE bad customer service, maybe I get this from my dad, but I will say something to your face if you're rude.

that said, I was finished ordering, and he stopped tending this other customers order to help me with getting a highchair for my lil' one. He even noticed how I was feeding my kid some of the burrito (the spinach tortilla is BOMB), and brought a water bottle out free of charge. 

It's litte things like that that get me to come back with a huge smile.

The burrito was good to, I wish they put more avacado in it, but hey at least I got some. And the way they melt the cheese onto the tortilla is just perfect. Spicy chicken is great too! Baby loved the burrito  :)
author: Sherrine K.

description: I enjoy this place it's generally super fast and the food is good. I like either the spicy chicken or beef. Anyway you get it is going to be good (i.e.) tacos, nachos, and so on.
author: Shawn A.

description: Chino's has always been a "I've got to go there soon" place on my walk down Balboa and now it has become "Is it okay to have Chino's for lunch and dinner?"  Five stars definitely for the value and incredibly friendly service.  $6.30 for a "Super" burrito which left nothing to be desired.  Fresh ingredients with no single overwhelming layer but everything you could ask for.  You probably won't need a whole burrito but it is near impossible to stop eating.  Note: The spicy chicken is really delicious but not too spicy so ask for extra hot sauce if thats your style.
author: Andrew H.

description: Another good Richmond district taqueria!  I've been going here since I was a child and the quality still remains the same (as well as most of the signage!).
author: Tim T.

description:
For a San Francisco burrito joint this place isn't very good which is sad cause it's very close to me.  

Why can't we get an El Farolito over in the Richmond Dist ?
author: A D.

description:
Stumbled upon this gem today with my sister and cousins... win!

Order up for a bunch of fatties:
1 carnitas quesadilla
1 chicken quesadilla
2 carne asada burritos
1 carne asada nacho order

I got the carnitas quesadilla and somehow, its natural flat appearance mutated into this massive, delish burrito (I had to get the works with it: rice, beans, salsa, guac, sour cream, and hot sauce).  All four of us were satisfied with our meals and left as happy, full customers.  BTW, it's cash only.
author: christina y.

description:
great burritos.  i haven't been here for a while, but next time i'm in the area, i will most likely get a burrito.

the staff is friendly and the taqueria is very casual.  i like this place a lot.
author: Amy L.

description:
Alriiiight.  

I ordered a Super Carne Asada Taco today and it tasted pretty bland.  It looked really good because there was a ton of sour cream, guacamole, and salsa but they couldn't hide how flavorless the carne asada tasted.  AND it was really hard to eat because it was so messy! Just a little disappointed because it's the neighborhood taqueria. 

I probably wouldn't come back unless it's a night like tonight...9:45pm on a Sunday and you're craving a taco.
author: Helen V.

description:
Let it be known that they wrap a solid burrito. 

It's definitely nothing special, but it gets the job done like an old honda. The place is not pretentious at all and the prices reflect that. Less than $6 for a well-balanced, flavorful enough food rocket that satisfies those lurking burrito cravings. No long lines, no crowds, just no-nonsense burrito action. 

The carne asada could have more flavor, but the rest of the fixins are spot on (guacamole being the best of them). The price is right and this 'rito does the trick.
author: Victor S.

description: Good prices, good portions.  Not the best for vegetarians, but acceptable.  I've been going here for years, and nothing in this price range is better.
author: Evan M.

description:
Come here with my boyfriend when we're in San Francisco's Richmond district craving for burritos. The burritos are okay but i've had better... i might be biased because i'm use to San Jose's Iguana's juicy burrito's and La Victoria orange sauce that spices up the burritos.

The nachos here is good but i don't recommend getting it with the steak. the streak or "carne asada" is usually kinda dry here and there isn't any special marination either. But if you're tight on the wallet i recommend coming here for the inexpensive food.
author: Jessica T.

description:
My favorite place to get a burrito!!!  Everyone has their own opinions of best burrito, but I grew up coming to this place and I always compare every burrito I eat to this.  I love the perfect sloppiness, richness, and flavors of this burrito.  Carnitas is yummy, carne asada is yummy, grilled chicken is my favorite or the spicy chicken... don't make me choose.  The guys who work and own this place are AWESOME, they are super cool and nice and always wait with a smile for my little sister to muster up the courage to say "gracias!" whenever we go.  I always take her here after school.

And THANK YOU for serving horchata! Not many places have it, or they have the kind that is in those boxy machines that always taste bad and chalky.   Over the years it's gotten pricey but I still go because I can't get enough of their burittos and quesadillas... and tacos... and corn quesadillas... and EVERYTHING.

Lastly, the murals on the wall are very striking and I appreciate them when I eat there.  It really completes the ambience for me!
author: Rachelle F.

description:
Ya ya Chino's! 

Great place. Super friendly dudes work there. Burritos are good and good for the money. Get the spicy chicken and a jarritos

Tacos are hard to eat so watch out, they're massive
author: Jay C.

description:
Hands down, the best chile verde in the city... and i've tried most of them... their other meat choices are good, too, esp the grilled chicken.

actually, this may be the best burrito in all of SF...
author: Neda B.

description: I went here today for the first time. My friend and I got the carnitas super nachos and a carnitas and carne asada tacos. The carnitas were delicious - flavorful and tender, but sadly, the carne asada was dry. I would come back and only order the carnitas. We ordered the nachos after someone ahead of us did and decided we had to get them too! The staff were fast, efficient and very pleasant. I wish they served beer also!
author: Chelsea H.

description: This place has really good burritos.  I love their spicy chicken!  Its the best I've had in any taqueria.  Everyone makes their burritos a different way, but I usually order a spicy chicken super "quesadilla" with a tomato tortilla.  The reason I put quesadilla in parenthesis is because its not your typical flat one with cheese and meat only.  This has everything! meat, rice, beans, sour cream, lettuce, pico de gallo, guacamole, hot sauce all wrapped into a size of a burrito and then grilled so the tortilla is kinda toasty.  Super good!  Plus its so convenient for me cause its the closest to my house. been going here since high school and will be always be as long as they stick around!
author: Gina S.

description: Sadly I used to love this place every time in the morning after a heavy night of drinking, but the food is only mediocre after having Mexican food in south bay and in the peninsula.  This is the best place in the local area in Richmond for Mexican food though.  The burritos they make are flexible in what kind of tortilla, salsa and meat it comes with.  The staff is friendly, which makes up for the mediocre food.  I would come here again if I were hungover and can't go anywhere else for Mexican.  =)
author: John H.

description:
Chino is Spanish for Chinese.  

If I was eating this food in Canada, I would be much more pleased.  But, since it is SF, (though a mostly Asian neighborhood) I expect a little more.  The roja and verde salsa are mediocre at best, and lettuce in a burrito is never a good idea.  The meat and beans are decent, as well as the speed and service.  I still eat there, since it is only two blocks from my house, but if I can plan my dinning out a little further in advance, I go somewhere else.
author: Pul F.

description:
Decided to come here to grab a quick lunch today...I always see people coming in and out of this place so it looked promising. Menu is pretty straightforward. Not a ton of variety - but it has your basics. The restaurant itself is a hole in a wall place - I think it's aimed to be a takeout place, but there are tables and chairs to sit and eat. Once you get there - you order - they make your food in front of you and you pay. 

We ordered the super carnitos burrito ($5.50) and the super carne asada nachos ($7). The "super" means whatever you order comes with salsa, guac., sour cream, your choice of meat, cheese, beans, rice, and lettuce. Everything was good- good portions too. There's nothing fancy about this place tho - but if you are looking to get something quick, this is the place!
author: Betty S.

description: Try the chile verde! Yummy porky goodness.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I've been coming here ever since the days of high school (SI alumni) when my friends introduced me back then like peer pressure with drugs and alcohol (I only drank). Nonetheless, this is definitely the place I go to get my fix for Mexican food when I'm in the area. And I find my appetite increases the colder and foggier the weather gets because it makes the trip out to the avenues that much more fun especially when it's a hidden gem of a great taqueria.

One thing to say, their SUPER BURRITOS ARE SO DELICIOUS. And at $6 w/ chips what you get is decent. The perfect combo for the Super Burrito goes like this: Spinach tortilla wrap w/ cheese + carnitas + black beans + everything else + touch of whip cream + spicy sauce = explosions on the tastebuds. They also have nachos here which are delicious too, tacos, enchiladas and a few other things. An extensive drink selection doesn't hurt too.

The 3-4 man staff is super FRIENDLY and PATIENT as well. Expect this place to be crowded during lunch hours on weekdays because of the highschool nearby and on some weekend nights. Another convenient quality is that they OPEN UNTIL 10PM WEEKLY! 

I enjoy coming back here for their food once in a while. Beware: they only accept cash, and make sure to balance with fiber, constipation can be an issue. Just saying!
author: Brandon H.

description: It ain't bad...and as people say, it is VERY friendly.  With that said, I am NOT a fan of the spicy chicken.  Why?  Cause it's not actually spicy.  And the rice here is almost always sodden and woefully overcooked.  Why 4 stars then?  2-3 for the food, +1 for the staff, +1 for the low, low, low price...always lures me in when I'm walking by.
author: Mike B.

description:
As others have said, living by OB leaves little options in the Mexican food department.

However, Chino's has been a savior countless times. A few blocks down from my house, they are almost always open, and seem to be a good group of guys who enjoy running the shop.

Spicy chicken super burrito on spinach tortilla, or chile verde super quesadilla are my go-to's. Everything has always been good and fresh.

They also have some beers and mexican coke.

One star away from perfect because it's cash only, they put lettuce in their stuff if you don't tell them not to, and come on, nothing's ever going to touch El Farolito in the mission.
author: Ryan M.

description: I've been coming here since I was 12 (now 30) and their burritos are always awesome and always fat as hell. Some of the younger guys can be a little stingy at times with ingredients but just tell them you want more and they are more than happy to comply. The actually place is always very clean, relaxed atmosphere & awesomely friendly staff. looking forward to my next burrito...
author: Katharine R.

description: So we moved a year ago (w/i SF) and this is now the only taqueria in walking distance.  i do like eating here but am giving just 3 stars as I am spoiled by great SF taquerias and wish my local (chinos) was a bit better.  So yeah, if you are not walking (but drving) just go to Gordo's on Geary or on Clement and you'll have better food for slightly less money too.
author: g m.

description:
I eat at Chino's on a regular basis and think that it is an absolute oasis in a the Outer Richmond. This taqueria offers the usual array of meat options and friendly staff. If I didn't have this place I'd be without my coveted Chili Verde Super Burrito.

(This is my first Yelp! review. Neat.)
author: Kevin R.

description: Good neighborhood spot, but they are stingy. I don't mind paying more for a double portion, but I shouldn't have to pay extra for a regular amount of guacamole or salsa. Chips are extra as are all sauces. I will continue to go when I have no alternative or am way too lazy to leave the Richmond. Otherwise, the place is clean and staff is friendly.
author: Irina S.

description:
Great food, friendly people, Chino's Taqueria is as good as it gets! I've been going here for over 15 years and I never get bored. 

They have a great variety, and their red tortillas are especially good. If you're really hungry order a "jumbo" burrito or quesadilla and you'll be full for days!

Only thing is it's cash only, which can be frustrating sometimes, but outside the mission district, Chino's is easily the best taqueria in the city. Their meats are really tasty and seasoned nicely, especially their chile verde and chile colorado. They also have great nachos if you're in the mood for a lot of food.

Bottom line, I'd recommend this place to anyone!
author: Maxim L.

description:
Decided to try this place since there is nothing else mex around here. 
Asked for extra hot sauce inside the burrito-this was the best part of the burrito otherwise it would have been plain. 

Its okayyyyyyy. I wish it was better so I wouldnt have to go so far to get a darn burrito for lunch. Has the opportunity to be a hidden gem in the richmond but does not make the cut. 

Hole in the wall, parking is limited.
author: Amy S.

description:
When you live in the way Outer Richmond, your Mexican food options are pretty limited. But sometimes you just need the comfort of a belly-filling burrito. Chino's is my savior in those situations.

I've only had their carne asada burrito but that's all I ever want when I stop by. I'm not going to say it's the best burrito I've had in SF but when my lazy butt can't muni down to the Mission, Chino's scratches my burrito itch. Service has always been fast and easy.
author: Tony S.

description: The spicy chicken is the ticket folks. These guys make a mean burrito for cheap. Glad it's in the hood!
author: Leanne S.

description:
Things were not looking good:

I was far from home (my beloved mission was a long ways away).
I was wet (hurray needed rain, not so hurray walking in it).
I was in pain (I'm over carry my work laptop around - need netbook ASAP).
I was hungry (or at was plotting my dinner needs).

Enter Chino's.

I think I read about this place on burritoeater.com or something like that remembering it getting rave reviews. They are well deserved. So many things to like - wheat tortillas, mounds of chicken soaking up a delicious green sauce, zero problem getting more black beans instead of rice, lettuce at no charge. And cheap - less than $6.

All came together for an excellent burrito, easily one of my favs, especially outside the mission.
author: Jason B.

description: Having read the fellow reviewers, I think the key word to Chino's is "neighborhood taqueria".  I love having a place where I can take a nice leisurely stroll with my family and have some decent Mexican food without breaking the bank ($40 feeds my family of 5 including drinks).  I've had some pretty tasty Mexican food in Tijuana...as well as in SoCal.  Do I compare those experiences to what I get at Chino's?  No...because I don't have time to fly down south just for Mexican food.  The guys that run this place know what they're doing...they serve solid food with excellent service.  For the out of town guests and those that try to compare the food here to the taquerias in the Mission district, if you got time to drive over to the Mission, be my guest.  Good luck finding parking over in the Mission.  At least around here, you have a better chance.  So leave Chino's to my family and I and the other neighbors in the area as we all love what they serve.  Started eating here as a single person and now my 3 young children are gobbling their food down as well.
author: Dominic L.

description:
A good, big burrito for $8 but nothing too special. They do have the option of spinach, tomato or flour tortilla. 

Felt rushed the whole time even though there was no one else in line behind me. Maybe they were close to closing?? It was only 7pm. I got mine to go since I live down the street, but the interior didn't look like an interesting place to hang out, though it does have plenty of seating.

 It was my first time there, but I'd say their carne asada burrito was better than the carnitas burrito I got at Gordo's last week. Good food, ok price, ok service. But willing to give it another shot.
author: Shannon M.

description:
MY FIRST MEAL OF 2009 was a super spicy chicken burito from chino's with no sour cream.
Amaaazing grace... how sweeet the taste........

god I miss California!

this place has never done me wrong.
author: Helen N.

description:
One of my favorite taquerias in San Francisco, I go here at least two times a week because they do not skimp on the veggies. Their guacamole has tomatoes and onions mixed with pepper unlike most burrito restaurants, they offer light but tasty salsa, and they have lettuce which is a rarity with burritos. I'm judging based upon taste alone. 

Minus one star because the very bottom portion of the burrito is always too wet and ends up making the bottom part a bit soggy.
author: Andrew O.

description:
I've lived in the Richmond District my entire life and have never ever noticed this place.  Granted, I don't live in the Outer Richmond, so that might be why.  

I was craving burritos for a while, so A decided to take care of the craving by taking me to his burrito joint of choice, Chino's.  It looks pretty small and ghetto on the outside, but it actually goes pretty far back.  You walk in and are at the counter right away.  You order, they make your burrito, you pay, then you either leave with your food, or you grab a seat at one of their tables.

I, as you all know, cannot take spicy food at all, but A convinced me that the spicy chicken would probably be the best for me and it really wouldn't be that spicy.  So, I trusted him and ordered the Spicy Chicken Burrito on the Spinach Tortilla.  It was really good and the prices were very reasonable.  The burrito was hardly spicy at all and it was tasty.  I didn't want to order something and get really dry meat in it.  That always sucks.  I also got some Watermelon soda.  I've never had watermelon soda before.  It was kind of odd.  But the burrito, was definitely two super yums up!
author: Kris L.

description:
Chino's was a complete and utter fluke discovery for me.  I'm currently living in the Richmond District.  Daily I fight the urge to go back to the area of the city that I lived in years ago, the Hayes Valley, and to the spots I used to visit when I lived there: Union Square, the Embarcadero, the Lower Haight, the Marina, the Fillmore district, etc. However, I've been good, and I'm being rewarded as I discover some great businesses here in the Avenues.

Yesterday, I was on the 38 Geary heading to the Safeway on La Playa.  Around 33rd Avenue, I noticed a cute corridor of cafes and restaurants on Balboa Street.  I was tempted to get off of the bus, but decided to stay on to see what was there because I'd double back after picking up some groceries.  Also, I'd not eaten lunch, so I was hungry.  We passed Chino's and I decided that was the spot.  

I'm glad I chose it.  They had the full spread in terms of different meats and other ingredients.  I ordered a carnitas super burrito because I love guacamole and their super burritos come with it.  They also have the choice of three different types of tortillas.  I chose the traditional flour one (and, sorry, I can't even tell you what the other two choices were.)

The only negative of the place was the line.  It wasn't necessarily their fault, but just bad timing on my part as I got stuck behind a woman who ordered I don't know how many things back to back instead of simultaneously.  They'd gear up to move on and then she'd start with another order.  That was really irritating because I was hungry.  However, there isn't much you can do in that situation outside of 1) suck it up and wait or 2) be a jerk.  I chose to suck it up, grimace and wait.

The guys taking working there were all nice.  The prices were great.  I paid just over $7 for a super burrito and a soft drink.  The best part was the burrito.  It was delicious and tasted just as delicious as the one made in the great taquerias in Southern California.  

I'll definitely make my way back over there before I leave the city. If you're in the area, definitely check them out.
author: Regina W.

description:
Why they say "Chino"?
They are Mexican, right?
i didn't know that China men were in Mexico.
Well, it doesn't matter to me.
I have been here so many times, for last 10 years, I think that's why I totally forgot to yelp about this great Taqueria.

Chino's + Simple Pleasure Cafe + Balboa Theatre = A heart of outer Richmond! 
They are good together forever!
Peace, Love,
author: Nobu K.

description:
I've been here plenty of times when I use to go to high school here.. Their burritos are pretty good, big, and cheap. Good spot for students and for people on a budget. I recently just came back here because I didn't feel like driving to El Farolito just to get some quesadillas so I came here.

Parking right in front I thought I scored. No line inside, another score. Cheap quesadilla, score again. Went home and my bag was full of the liquids coming out of my quesadilla. DISAPPOINTED and pissed. My tortilla was all soggy but I still ate it cuz I was starving. Hardly ANY sour cream, which is my favorite. Skimpy on my carne asada... made me sad. I never finish my quesadillas wherever I go but I ate the whole thing from Chino's.. you know what that means.. It's too small for me.. 

Next time, I'll stick with their burritos..
author: Juliane N.

description:
Your basic tasty neighborhood taqueria. My boyfriend and I go every Tuesday, the  burritos aren't mindblowing, but hey! they're reliably tasty. Try the spicy chicken (get extra hot sauce; the flavor is good, but it's not too spicy), or the chile verde, which is my favorite.

The staff is awesome, too.
author: Lesley P.

description:
Chino's Taqueria - next best thing to not traveling to the Mission if you're a Richmond District dweller.

Fresh, tasty, big portions, and cheap.

My only complaint - spice up that salsa Mexican style! Mas Caliente!
author: Liz K.

description:
If you want a good burrito when you're in the Outer Richmond, there's always Chino's. I know about this place because my brother is unfortunate enough to have to live all the way out there. I know it's not saying much, but this is the best taqueria in the entire Richmond District. The ingredients are fairly fresh, the service is fast, and there's always room to sit. Plus, if you'd like coffee or tea, you can always walk two doors down to Simple Pleasures, the best coffeehouse in the Richmond.

One word of caution: If you're white, one of the employees will inevitably make fun of you in Spanish to his coworker. (The perpetrator is the short burrito preparer who wears a bandana.) I'm not sure if he does it on purpose, though, because I've seen many gringo customers razz him right back in Spanish.

Bottom line, this place is great, and it makes all the fog bearable. Sort of.
author: John S.

description:
I've always wondered what goes on in Outer Balboa during a weekday, and the answer is: not much.  Sure, at 5:30 the streets are packed with throngs of locals celebrating their liberation from the 38-Geary, but who actually works around here during the day?  Exaaaactly.  The only other guy getting lunch at Chino's was picking up a massive take-out order for a construction crew.  Now, few restaurants are particularly appealing when they're empty, but you know what they say: it's the burritos, stupid.

On that front, Chino's is certainly in the upper echelon, and if you can navigate the cryptic and at times contradictory menu boards, you'll notice a little thing at the bottom: "Jumbo: $8.00".  This would be the jumbo burrito, possibly the biggest one I've seen in San Francisco yet, which they prudently wrap in double tortillas to avoid fallout (naturally we split--and even then it was a big meal).  The balance of ingredients was superb as well--carnitas, black beans, cheese and toppings in perfect harmony.  Can't fault any part of it, hence it's gotta be 5 stars.

If you're not from the nabe, make the most of your long journey by nabbing a coffee at Simple Pleasures afterwards.
author: Wes M.

description:
I like the service here. The chefs seem to make everyone feel at ease with their jovial interaction. The burritos are usually pretty good...as good or better than Gordo's. 

Parking can usually be found, if no place else in front of the fire hydrant if you're not eating in. 

There is not much else for quick Mexican, out here in the outer outer outer Richmond.
author: Kevo M.

description:
It saddens me to give this place one star. If it weren't for the late night stomach cramps it definitely would have been higher. 

When I was first looking for a place to live in San Francisco I checked out a spot right next to this taqueria. It smelled delish and I've thought of it ever since. It was finally time to go on a mission and find this heaven for my nose. There was a line out the door and everyone seemed to know exactly what they wanted: a SUPER burrito! Of course I followed the pack and got a super burrito as well. This custom burrito was packed to the brim with carnitas, beans, rice, cheese, guacamole, sour cream, pico, and hot sauce. I could only finish half of the head sized burrito and I wrapped up the rest to save for later. As we walked out I told the cook it was so I good! I'll be back! 

I wont go into details, but later that night I decided I would NOT be going back, and I sadly threw away the other half of the burrito.

If you have a cast iron stomach (which it seems everyone in that long line did) Chino's is the place to go for a big ass burrito!
author: Casi C.

description:
I've been here 3 times and have since decided to not come back.

The food lacks flavor and isn't good.  Even the salsa completely lacks flavor...and it's salsa!!  The fresh salsa was the worst salsa I've ever had.  It was chopped tomatoes with chopped white onions...and THAT WAS IT.  What the hell?    It was just like eating watery diced tomatoes...no cilantro, no salt, no flavor!

Once I had come for a late dinner with a friend.  We were tired and hungry, and we sat down to eat.  It apparently was closing time, but we didn't realize.  One of the guys working there came over and  turned off the lights in the area we were sitting.  If you didn't want us there, then you shouldn't have served us!!  

The Richmond is lacking in Mexican places, but as much as I might want Mexican food, I won't be coming here!!
author: Liz C.

description:
what a gem! prices are great. I had the spicy chicken burrito with rice, beans, lettuce and salsa.. MMM. fresh, well prepared, and not heavy at all (i usually expect to fall asleep after eating mexican).

AND the staff is super nice. Definitely going back!
author: tessie n.

description:
Not so good.
As usual, I think the meat eaters are in on something I'm not. :)

I tried the veggie burrito, and although it's edible, I thought the salsas left a bit to be desired.  The salsa fresca is TASTELESS, and the salsa verde is watered down AND tasteless.  Not a good combo.  The salsa roja is actually OK, but the rice is boring, the beans are flavorless, and the guacamole isn't very deep in it's green-ness; more light.

I wasn't impressed, plus got a bit of a creepy vibe.
I actually like Gordo a bit better, and I don't even have much to say about Gordo.

I don't think I'll be back here.
author: linden d.

description:
I will only say this once....

BEST BURRITO IN TOWN!

The meat is flavorful and the options are plenty. You have several flavors of  wraps...I always order mine with the spinach tortilla. They also make their chips fresh. I love the super nachos. 

Minus 1 star for not serving hard taco's
author: Jamie K.

description:
1. This is not the Mission(but I think it's ok)
2. The burritos here are not that bad,quite yummy I must say and the prices are decent
3.  Different meats,creamy quacamole and crunchy chips
4.  You can see them make your food
5.  Get here before the rush(weeknights/weekends) and perhaps dine in.Only a few tables,but hey if you can't wait to indulge why not eat in here.
6.   Ask for extra and they will splash it on.


Overall,I have been here plenty of times and I have enjoyed my meal each time.The only thing is the parking and that depends on what time you come here.Parking can be a pain,but don't let that stop you from trying this place out.

Even though there are only a few tables here,well I have had luck in having a decent...well stuff my face meal here many times.

Friendly service.

Again,If you don't want to go out to the Mission and live in this area try this spot out.People have different taste,but if you just want something different to try come to Chino's.


Super Chicken Burrito and Nachos fill me.
author: Dani D.

description:
This place is a blessing for richmond dist. dwellers. SO much better than Gordo's and Tommy's. Why is this place the best? The food is always freshly prepared daily, them beans, carnitas and spicy chicken are made right there. An institution! 

My favorite is the spicy chicken "quesadilla". I also love the carnitas burrito "plain", They make it as huge as a "super" but instead of cheese, guac and sour cream they add more meat; get it spicy and with pic de gallo- its only $5!!!!

SO yo! this place is a blessing

-warning-
No carnitas sometimes till noon or later. Still cooking.
author: William H.

description:
Average tasting burritos.

I had Chino's beef burrito with black beans, guacamole, sour cream, and cheese.  The beef was kinda dry and flavorless.  Not much going on with the rest of the ingredients either.  The meat and beans were kinda lukewarm too.

The burrito did satisfy my appetite. For about $5, I'd say its a decent bargain.

Borderline 3 stars.
author: Sam T.

description:
Being a local, this is my go-to spot for a quick burrito or plate. Good, solid food, done well and with speed.

The folks behind the counter are personable and nice and deal well with all the varied types that show up; parents distracted with kids, the bra' with two years' high school Spanish under his belt, the hungrified from Simple Pleasures, and all the diverse neighborhood hungry.

Certainly solid in terms of quality, though not amazingly fantastic. Still, servings are consistent. Have been here many, many times (I mentioned it being local, right?) and what you get one time is what you get the next.

I will go here again easily as often as I've been here before.
author: Bob M.

description:
That's the way... uh huh uh huh... I like it...
That's the way... uh huh uh huh... I like it...

I'm singing about the way I like my burrito and Chino's knows the recipe to make me sing!

I used to live around the corner and this was my regular spot.  Now I live not as close by but close enough to get my fix when a craving calls.  

Chino's appears small and narrow but when you walk in there is plenty of space to grab a table and enjoy your meal.  I've tried the nachos, quesadillas, tacos, burritos and I've never been disappointed! Everything is good, I personally love the carnitas, never fatty always plentiful.  

Speaking of fatty, Gordo's is way overrated next time try Chino's and you will be singing too!
author: Frankie F.

description:
Whoa...anybody dropping 5 stars here really needs to have their Yelp license revoked.  

I was passing by here on a cloudy Saturday afternoon when I felt my stomach a growlin', and knew a burrito would really hit the spot.  The inside of Chino's is ummm...."authentic".  In other words, pretty ghetto.  Like, you're surprised not to see roaches and are worried at any moment the big bad wolf may show up and blow the whole place down.  I opted for the Spicey Chicken burrito and felt it was fine although the "Spicey" part was a bit of a mystery.  Lots of rice, tomato, beans, and onion that reminded me more of Taco Bell than Los Compadres, although I will say it beat Gordo hands down.  

I'm tempted to 2-star here in order to even things out, however, 3-star is most accurate because the food is OK, the prices are low, and the staff seems cool.  But I got a feeling people are usually hitting Chino's after a few hours of sun, water, and cheap beer at the beach.  Coming here on a a cloudy day when you're sober is gonna be a let-down.
author: John H.

description: Have been going to Chino's since I was a student at Washington and I keep going back. Cheap,tasty, close to home and always good memories! The spicy chicken is definitely my number one choice and if its no a super burrito im goin for the super nachos!!! Staff is friendly as well. Only cons are the bathroom is disgusting and you can forget about getting food between 11:30-12:30 cause thats when all the washington high school kids are out to lunch
author: Anthony M.

description:
El chino's super burritos and I go way back, like high school friends.  I still can't believe I haven't paid homage with a review to one of my hometown favorites. - this should have been my first entry.  

Even though it's located in the Richmond, everything about the place screams authentic Mexican food, from their murals to the mouth watering smell of all the meats and marinades.

I like my orders simple: super carne asada burrito on a spinach tortilla with everything and green hot sauce, por favor!!!!  

In case you ever succumb to a super burrito craving, remember to bring cash, or else you'll end up wandering up and down the street for the nearest ATM while cursing and kicking yourself because you forgot, for the second time damnit...  Note: there's a cafe two doors down with an ATM.  =)
author: Joji M.

description:
Stumbled on this place awhile back and make it a point to stop in periodically whenever I'm craving something non-Asian here in Outer Richmond.

The burritos: ¡muy excelente!

Service is always quick and thorough.

Bring your greens, because they don't accept anything but bills minted by the US Treasury. The good news is you won't need many of them because the food is super affordable.

It's a little bit of a dive inside and out, but not unwelcoming. OK, maybe the iron bars have confused me whether they were open, closed, or a licensed outpost of the overcrowded penitentiary system, but I have to imagine that prison food would never be quite so delicioso.
author: Aaron H.

description:
This is my favorite Taqueria in the city. These guys feed me regularly and they are so cool. They even let me slide if Im a little short, instead of making me go to the bank. ;) 

The Burrittos are so damn good, I have a hard time resisiting that place. I also love the grilled chicken tacos, quesadillas, nachos, you name it, they rock it. I am not allowed to go in there for a while though, due to the new year resolution. Check em out, you will be hooked!
author: Mary K.

description:
Chino's.  My most visited place on Balboa throughout 4 years of High School.  The simple menu and reasonable prices has kept me coming back ever since.  
Before High School I had only dined at Gordo's so needless to say the nachos and refried beans, offered only by Chinos at the time, rocked my world.  Super nachos, extra cheese with carne asada, the works.  One of the first meals I remember being disappointed about not finishing.  Everything is good here, not great but things are as they should be.  Three stars for not taking credit cards and for not giving my friend a free hat after he found a rock in his burrito.
Cheers!
author: Casey C.

description:
This is not central mexican its more like northern style, which caters to American people. I like the burritos. Cant complain. if you want spicy food  eat Indian food.

If you want good mexican food go to Mexico City or puebla, michoacan, ixtepec where it takes 1-2 days of intense labor to prepare the food. Thats good food.  

Chinos is a "Taqueria" not  a Mexican Restaurant
author: James R.

description:
CHiN0`S iS FREAKiN` AWES0ME! ;]  i`VE BEEN C0MiNG HERE SiNCE i WAS AB0UT 4 YEARS 0LD...PARTiALLY BECAUSE i WENT T0 PRESCH00L ACR0SS THE STREET FR0M THERE, ELEMENTARY SCH00L RiGHT BEHiND iT, MiDDLE SCH00L A FEW BL0CKS AWAY FR0M iT, HiGH SCH00L UP THE BL0CK FR0M iT && MY PARENTS 0WNED THE ViDE0 RENTAL ST0RE RiGHT NEXT T0 iT BACK iN `91!  S0 i GUESS Y0U C0ULD SAY iT`S DESTiNY?

ANYWAY, S0 F0R THE PAST 17+ YEARS, i`VE ALWAYS 0RDERED THE SAME THiNG...A CHEESE QUESADiLLA WiTH S0UR CREAM, LETTiCE && RiCE.  && F0R THE PAST 17+ YEARS, iT HAS BEEN AWES0ME!  iT STiLL TASTE LiKE iT DiD 17 YEARS AG0 WHEN i FiRST BiT iNT0 0NE, && iT`S STiLL BEiNG MADE BY THE SAME GUY T00!  LoLx  N0THiNG`S CHANGED...N0T THE CHEFS, N0T THE F00D...&& i L0VE iT!

i PRETTY MUCH GREW UP EATiNG CHiN0`S QUESADiLLAS...iT`S 0NE 0F MY C0MF0RT F00DS! :]
author: Dee W.

description:
AWESOME!!! I love an excuse to get chinos!!!! I'm a fan of the carne asada, black bean, cheese, no sour or guac, with hot sauce and lettuce.

mmmmmmmmmmmmmm
author: Dana M.

description:
The burrito was yummy.  I won't deny that.  

However, the taste did not stand out in my memory as much as the fact that it fell apart.  Burritos are self-contained yumminess that you should be able to eat anywhere out of their foil wrappers.  This burrito was just not so.

Both mine and my boy's collapsed.  There was so much sauce that it dripped like hell and could not stand up on it's own.  We had to resort to a fork and knife.  Not cool.

Tasted ok but disappointed.  I'll probably continue at Gordo's for that reason.
author: Melissa Q.

description:
What is this place good for? Quick lunch breaks, hangover food, and people who want to get full on a budget. I love this place.

Although they do make other things (nachos, etc.) this place is all about the burritos. They are made to order and it is one of those places that you stand there and tell them everything you want in your burrito and they make it in front of you. 

Of course this isn't gourmet mexican food but it is damn good mexican food. The burrito is big and for around 5 bucks you can't go wrong. Definitely a TO GO place but you can eat there if you need to.

Very nice people there too.
author: Josh J.

description:
The best thing about this place is the spicy chicken. It's the only place I can find it. Everything else is just run of the mill mexican food. The nachos can't compare to most other places, and the only reason for eating a burrito is the spicy chicken. They don't even give you free chips and salsa. I still prefer this place to Gordos though.

2.5
author: Colin H.

description:
Interesting and simple setup inside. The menu is pretty barebones (perhaps all taquerias are like this? I don't frequent them enough...), service seemed decent though. The men behind the counter called me "Senorita" which I thought was cute. They also seemed prepared for either the "eat-in" or "takeout" options...the little plastic baggy was all ready for if a customer should say "to go please". 

I've only lived in this neighborhood for a couple of months now, and every time I passed by Chino's before, I always thought the place was super small. I thought there were only two tables in the whole place, but today I saw that there's a bigger seating area inside (off to the side, away from the doorway). 

Now, onto the burrito itself--I'm no burrito connoisseur like my friend Mellie P., so I can't say if the burrito I ate today was super-duper delicious, or if it was bland. Burritoeater.com states that Chino's is not that great, although it's working its way up there....seems like a lot of Yelpers however really love Chino's.

For me, Chino's is middle of the ground, at least for now. I had a burrito with carnitas; the hot sauce was a pretty good addition to the burrito itself. I passed on the guacamole and sour cream due to the fact that I know those two condiments have a ton of fat and calories (and you may ask, why is a calorie counter eating a burrito in the first place?). 

Anyway, I did like how they had their chip bags arranged in front of the counter AND in good, single-serving portions, too! Kudos on that. Seems like a decent neighborhood place with decent food and prices. I'm a little scared about the jumbo-sized option....I already felt really full after eating my "regular" burrito.
author: Helene K.

description: DH and I lived in the Outer Richmond for 5 years and it was one of our favorite spots (although when we came back from a 14-day bland-fest on our honeymoon in England and Ireland, we ditched our suitcases, jumped in the  car and made a beeline for La Taqueria in the Mission instead, drooling all the way). Anyway we've both eaten a lot of taqueria fare and agree that generally Chino's is really good - a great deal for the money. Now, living in Alameda if I get hit with craving/nostalgia for life in the Outer Richmond, Chinos' is  usually my first choice. The Kid and I went there in summer of 2010 - she had the super quesadilla and I had the super burrito; neither of us finished them and were thrilled to have a taqueria breakfast the next day. Being a hole-in-the wall, it may not be your thing. I'm amazed at how varied the reviews are!
author: Alana D.

description:
Well I have been here twice so I guess I can say that I would it here again..I usually love a good Carne asada burrito but the meat looked 
Hella dry so I could not get it either time.

I had the chicken and though I usually don't order the chicken it was okay had some flavor it should from sitting in all that red sauce. I hate a burrito place that charges you for chips...

And when you acyually pay the 50 cents there Friggin Stale Uh Uh ...The chips were tired..

The food is okay at least they have a spot in this area Not Fresh enough for my taste
author: Kim R.

description:
Authentico burritos muy delicioso.  Disclaimer:  I've only had burritos here, and they are awesome!  The best San Francisco burritos outside of the Mission that I've had yet.

For the gringos who call this place bland, don't be a wuse and put some hot sauce on there!  Their verde and their roja are both really good.
 
Auf.
author: Dave K.

description: Ok, so I haven't eaten here, but my roommates have.  I'm giving them 5 stars for the bottle of E&J that they keep under the counter.
author: Michael G.

description:
I don't know what I would do without the carnitas at Chinos. All their food is great, but their carnitas take the cake. Juicy, flavorful, and always in generous portions. 

The burritos are the size of your head.

Their meats are all delicious, the spicy chicken is another favorite of mine. If you want something a little lighter than a burrito, try the tacos (ok. They aren't lighter at all. You get tons of food on top of two corn tortillas. But somehow, it seems a little lighter.)

Their guacamole - tastes great, I wish they would use more avocado and less filler - but overall, it satisfies the craving...

The cooks are talented *and* speedy, with personalities to match - kind, humorous and friendly. 

The only real bummer - I wish it had a nicer sit-down feel. Maybe a plant or two and nice lighting. But whatever - as long as I get my carnitas...
author: Robin G.

description:
Living closer to the Richmond makes for a long venture to the Mission for burritos.  I'd seen Chino's in passing but I'm leary of taqueria's west of the Mission District.  Today I was starving and didn't feel like going far.

I picked up 2 burritos for lunch.  I ordered carne asada with the red hot sauce added & my lover got carnitas with the non-spicy salsa/pico de gallo stuff.

First thing I noticed is that the carne asada is sitting in its own juices as opposed to sitting dry.  I'd never had it like this before and it was pretty damn juicy.  The red hot sauce is flavorful...not made to fuel rockets, thankfully.  The juices and the hot sauce did make the burrito a bit soggy but it was expected.  It did not drip out of the foil.  The carnitas was delicious and not too salty.  My lover ate three quarters, waited a half-hour,  then couldn't resist finishing it.

FINALLY, FINALLY!  An above-avergae burrito outside the Mission.  Of course its no Castillito but it will do the trick.
author: Pete M.

description:
Love Chino's.  All the food is outstanding - burritos, tacos, quesadillas.  What makes the place, though, is the dudes behind the counter, who don't bat an eye when I have 9 orders, 8 of them bizarre custom orders like carnitas and green sauce, and nothing else, on a wheat tortilla.  (Seriously, WTF is that?)  Instead, they just act like what I want is the most natural thing in the world, and they whip it up right them and there, no big deal.  I love that.

They are nice and professional and superb and tasty.  My only issue is that they don't have fish tacos, but what they have is fantastic.
author: John H.

description: Frisco has some amazing food. But leave the burritos (and Mexican food) to us Southerners (LA I'm not including you, you guys are just aight)
author: Mario S.

description: Pretty great for the price. Only $5.50 for a super burrito with everything. The entire west part of SF is pretty limited, burrito-wise, so this was a nice find.
author: Zach D.

description:
I dig on Chino's.

Good Service, Good Burritos, and Good Prices.

The spicy chicken is my favorite, my only complaint is sometimes my burritos rip! Argh. I still always go back!
author: Jason P.

description:
a spot named after my hometown?! althought it's not quite up to par with the taquerias from back home in SoCal (where you can try a REAL burrito) Chino's is pretty damn close and it clearly beats anyplace else (including the Mission) in the city - both for the taste and the price.

all the meats are spiced fairly well and they have all the fixins you need to top it off. the fellas preparing you food are always quick and helpful too.

this place really hits the spot after a long session in the water at Ocean Beach.
author: Art O.

description: Brings back memories. I used to eat here in high school during lunch with friends. They have pretty good burritos and nachos and very big portions. I haven't been here since but I'll just base the review on back then. My favorite thing to get is the spicy chicken burrito without beans and everything on it. The food was also reasonably priced at the time. I wasn't always sure about the quality though or how fresh everything was. So it's usually a hit or miss with this place but good if you're a starving student on a budget, and it's right a few blocks from Wash.
author: Petra S.

description: Man I use to come here very often back in high school when I went to Washington. I LOVE this place. The best Mexican food place I've been to. I usually get their rice bowls. I'm a small eater generally speaking so it filled me up. YUM-O. Once I got a burrito that I share with my friend and boy was that burrito HUGE. But of course, it was delicious. Their spicy rice and chicken really hits the spots along with guac, sour cream and hot sauce. I've been here recently again and it is still just as delicious as I remembered. Plus this place is cheap! Delicious and cheap food. What a great combo!!
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
I went to the little Catholic school on 39th and Balboa up through 8th grade which was years past, and I never even stepped foot into this place until this year. Maybe because it was called Chino's and I was under the impression it was not going to be authentic especially having experienced the horrors from the Celia's on Judah or Tommy's on Geary!  Anyhow,  TAIL BETWEEN MY LEGS, HEAD HANGING LOW, I WAS WRONG!!!!!  I had definitely heard about this place over the years, but when  it was when my brother-in-law and sister that had finally inspired me to finally try this place because this was "their place" when they were "GOING" back in the days, I had to go and seek out what I was missing, I was pleasantly surprised. I had no idea that I could get decent Mexican food in "the Richmond." I am used to getting my Mexican/ Latino food in the Mission where I attended high school, so naturally that's where I'd go for it. 

     The food  at Chino's is fresh, good, cheap, delicious, perfect for hitting up before going to Ocean Beach, and for any other time you need a quick, delicious, local bite!!!!!!

    Thank you Chino's, I am sincerely humbled.
author: Granolia G.

description:
In the Richmond District you have two choices for great Burritos: Gordo's or Chino's. I prefer Gordo's but every once in a while I'll get a craving for Chino's that needs to be satisfied immediately. 

Chino's has: ample seating, kick-ass Super Nacho's, a wide selection of soda's (hey, it's important to me alright??), and parking is pretty easy to find.

I do however avoid it at all costs around lunch time during the weekdays due to the excessive amount of high school kids that hang out there.
author: Justin B.

description:
I was famished the night my husband brought home a couple of burritos from Chino's and was on mine like white on rice. Unfortunately that pretty much described the experience.

Due to  the large proportion of rice to other contents the burrito was understandably  on the bland side and fell apart easily, but overall was not 'bad', just not outstanding.
author: GIR ..

description:
Great food. Amazing prices. Friendly staff. I discovered this place almost 20 years ago! A fresh, unique and tasty take on the burrito. An affordable pick.

They offer a choice of 3 kinds of beans and 2 kinds of chicken (including spicy) as well as a wide range of other meats. They take the name 'Chino' from the Spanish word for Chinese as they borrow from the neighborhood's primary culinary influence.

I get a 3 bean (all three beans) with cheese, rice & salsa verde and and corn quesadilla (just cheese) and an order of chips & extra salsa verde.

Open from 10-10 they are always a good 'go-to' when you are hungry, broke or both.
author: Dre D.

description:
We love Chinos. Been going there for years. They have some of the best burritos in the city. We used to live in the Outer Richmond and moved about 6 years ago to the Inner Sunset. We still go over to Chinos to get burritos on a fairly regular basis.

One important thing to note, Chinos is a dive. If you want a fancy, super clean atmosphere, don't go there. But if you want inexpensive, consistent, good solid food, then Chinos is the place to go.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Best spicy chicken burrito I've ever had!!!! I always ask them to put some jalapenos in it too, and they always do =). It's a little wet, but oh so flavorful!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Get your own drink at the fridge, before they ring you up.

Nuff said.
author: Charles K.

description:
i prefer Chinos to Gordos (but Gordos is tasty too)
its down the street from my house and i come here when im craving mexican for lunch. i also send my friends up here when we are daydrinking bc the portions are huge and we can all sit inside. the chips and salsa are great.  they have really good choices of meat, again the portions are huge. if someone can tell me the difference between a quesadilla and a burrito from here my world will make a little more sense.
yup. i go with the quesadilla every time. i also get a mexican coke from the back
awesome meal followed by a food coma 99.9% of the time
author: Katherine C.

description: Hole-in-the-wall restaurants are usually either really good or really bad. This place is terrible. Yes, you get a lot of food for the price, but who wants bland chicken in their taco? I even ordered mine with the spicy chicken so who knows how awful (i.e. boring) the regular chicken would be. Add some flavor, please.
author: Amy F.

description: I love their spicy chicken burrito.  Only thing I ever order.  The flavor is outstanding!  Hole in the wall but it's been this way for years.  If you're in the neighborhood it is the best place to eat.
author: Karen C.

description:
my mouth is in mouring
for my chicken burrito was boring

the red "hot" sauce was bland
and i throw up my hands

though i work down the street
at chino's again i will not eat :(
author: Miharu Y.

description:
Not alot of taqueria choices in the richmond, but We are lucky to have Chino's (& Gordo's) around. A better value than Gordo's, actually a much better value since i always seem to have to beg the servers at gordos to scoop in a little more rice or meat or beans.

Guys at Chino's are are lot nicer and laid back. I usually order the super burrito, which comes with guac and sour cream. 

Still a fan of Gordos but glad Chinos is around.
author: w l.

description:
4 stars for 

1 friendly service
2 decent parking
3 better than Gordos
4 best I can do in Richmond since I don't live in the Mission

I'm always up for it.
author: Sue U.

description:
I used to live out here, and fortunately found this taqueria.  Not where most people think a great taqueria would be, but I haven't found a better burrito in San Francisco.  It's great, and I still go out of my way on occasion to go here, because it's worth it.  And great prices.
Oh, and they have Coke in glass bottles, which I'm partial toward, and seems to be harder to find recently.
author: Chris M.

description:
If you find yourself

A. With $1
B. Really cold
C. Really hungry
D. In need of shelter for approx. 15 minutes while your roommate is on the bus,

you should consider Chino's Taqueria! I went there with a buck and I'll tell you what I thought:

First off, the two people in front of me ordered burritos and they LOOKED amazing. The guy right in front of me had melted cheese on his and oh my, I wanted to ask him if I could have it. They two guys working gave it to him on the house, so I think he's a regular (which makes me want to become a regular.... eventually). Anyways, I asked for Chips & Salsa. The chips are fifty cents and then add another twenty-five cents for the "salsa" which was actually chopped up tomatoes. They lose a star for not having salsa. But other than that I really liked the set up of the place. It was extremely casualthentic. 

I'm going back for one of those burritos. And I'm taking my roommate.
author: Lauren O.

description:
Since it's merely a few blocks away, Chino's fills my ever-so-often Mexican cravings. 

Not sure how some people gave this place such an incredibly low rating. I guess bad food happens to good people all the time.

For fast Mexican, Chino's is a great spot. Their nachos, burritos and tacos are right on time. I usually stick with the beef (and small cubes of beef are ALWAYS on the dryer side; comes with the territory).

So, your experience is as follows: you walk in, look at the menu board, and get in line. The person behind the sneeze glass asks you what you want. Let's say, you want the nachos (because, I know  you do), he'll place a group of chips on a piece of tin foil covered in shredded cheese. He then places that foil in a steamer. Once he pulls it out and asks you "for here or to go" or (if you're fluent "para aqu o ir") - now, comes time to pick your toppings:

meat: spicy chicken or beef are your better options
beans: re-fried of course, the black beans are a close second though
vegetables: pico de galo, shredded lettuce
misc: guacamole, sour cream and opt for the hot sauce

Now, you're good to go. If you have other items such as tacos, burritos or quesadillas, you run down the same options. Simply, easy, cheap and worth the money and time spent. 

note: cash only and if you want to eat there, plenty of space (except during lunch time - high school kids galore).
author: Randall B.

description:
half steak half spicey chicken in a tomato wrap... no guac

best burrito in the city
author: Hank B.

description:
will you be mine, could you be mine, won't you be my neighbor.
I've been to Chino's a few times in the last couple months.
or was it I've been there a couple times the last few months?
Asada Super Burritos are good, me gusto me gusto.
is it the best mexican spot in the city?
well, it's the only one on Balboa.
if you are OR on your way to the Balboa theater and 
crave that meaty, cheesy, hot and spicy filled tortilla.
go get one.

why do they call it chino though when all the guys that work there are mexican?
author: al k.

description:
"Meh" ~ about sums it up.

Desperate for a burrito?  Don't want to drive too far? Like your guacamole from a can?  This is the place.

That said, Spicy Chicken is not horrible~ is ok for a burrito fix~ and the price is right.  (I will take Taqueria Cancun whenever I can get it...but live NOWHERE near the Mission....so...?)
author: Serena A.

description: I was severely unimpressed by the food that I consumed here.
author: Jennifer P.

description: Despite being a bit rough around the edges, this is a pretty satisfying Mexican food joint  that offers vegetarian ingredients -- surprisingly hard to come by in SF. It's also much more reasonable in price than some of the more popular (read: white yuppie) burrito places nearby (Gordo, Papalote).
author: Catherine T.

description: I've been going here for three years because it's near my martial arts school. It's ok food, nice folks. But last night I got sick from their food. I am never going there again. It's not even that good. And definitely not worth the crushing stomach pain and night of nausea.
author: Katherine T.

description:
Mmmm Chino's.....*drool*
I love this place! The guys are super friendly and the burritos are to die for. The spicy chicken is the best. Prices are fair too.
If you feel like having a burrito coma, order the jumbo. Holy Mackrel! Two huge tortillas side by side full of burrito goodness and rolled up into a ginormous 15" burrito. Whew...you're gonna need your turkey pants for it...
author: Judith F.

description: Great burrito spot somewhere else than the Mission.Under $7 for a burrito with everything on it.. if you are feeling really hungry get the jumbo its 2 tortillas overlapping and filled to the max for like $2.50 more. I've had plenty of friends get it claiming they would finish it but i am yet to see the day..
author: Craig B.

description:
I'm quite picky when it comes to burritos (only place I've ever liked em at is in Newark) so I'm not even going to start reviewing this place based on such a biased topic. instead, i would like to award special mention to the super nachos at Chino's. spicy chicken - oh yeah baby, right there.

large portions on the nachos, and the staff is always right on.

you wanna know about their burritos? tough, go check another review.
author: Darrell L.

description:
When it comes to burritos my reviews get serious.  I consider my self one of the top burrito connoisseurs in the city.  Mainly because I love burritos with a passion...  

I like Chinos - for a Richmond Taqueria.  The Richmond is limited to a handful of taquerias, half of which are Gordos.  Chino's has good prices, decent sized burritos and quick service.  On the other hand the flavor of most of their meats is fairly average, they don't have very good salsa and they DON'T give you free chips(horrible), not to mention its hella far away!  But if you find yourself in the outer Richmond and you're sick of Gordos, check out Chinos.  

Go for the Red Chicken - pretty good.
author: Justin O.

description:
I thought these guys had really good food which was much better than what Gordo tends to serve. I will have to go back and try some of their other stuff.

I strongly recommend checking out their stuff and trying out some of their other dishes.
author: Amlan S.

description:
Well..... I say 4 stars on my burrito and Negative [-3] on this spicy chicken quesadilla.
 I've been coming to Chinos for over 10 years now. I'm 23 and they've been open since i was in elementary school at Lafayette just a couple blocks from Chinos. I've been coming to chinos after school for years till I moved to LA. BUT my parents still live here so I still eat here, but the last year or so they've been going WAY DOWN HILL!!! I use to rate all there food 4-5 stars and I use to eat there quesadilla all the time, but today was the WORSE quesadilla EVER! oh and FYI there's some new dude who works here and he sucks at making them.. He's made 3 of them for me over the past year and each time there blah, but like i said tonight was the WORSE! I also ordered a burrito just in case. It was amazing; The quesadilla was falling apart and the dude rolls it like a god damn burrito and he hardly put any cheese and the cheese wasn't even melted all the way and! he puts the chicken after he takes it off the grill.. they use to put the cheese in it and grill it for awhile then through the chicken in and grill it up then put it in a box, but now its a nasty roll of yuck. Also the horchata use to be BOMB! Now it also a Negative [-3] ... 

So whatever you do just stick with the burritos. 

Adios 
AshUHley
author: Ashley M.

description: Ummm... Not much to say about this place. First off, they only take cash, so be prepared. It smelled amazing when I walked in, but the burrito and chips I ordered were ridiculously flavorless. Major let down. An okay option if you live in the area and want to grab a cheap burrito without trekking off somewhere that actually serves a tasty one.
author: Andria M.

description:
I have eaten at almost every burrito joint in SF, and Chino's makes hands down one of the best burrito's in the city. I am not a vegetarian, but I have a best friend who is almost borderline militant about his preferences and Chino's scores WAY up there on the list for the tiny things you want to see your favorite taqueria going out of the way to make sure your food isn't getting the same treatment as the rest of our lard/meat lovers food is. 

Naw, seriously. The burritos here kick ass. Cheap. Friendly. Fast. Except yes at lunch time, then be prepared for a possible line.
author: j d.

description: Chino's does not have much in the way of ambiance, but the food is so incredible, you hardly notice (I do takeout mostly, anyway). Their spicy chicken burrito is so delicious, it makes a trip out to the Mission totally unnecessary. The staff is very friendly as well - I highly recommend them to any fan of Mexican food!
author: Andrea N.

description:
There's not a lot I expect from a taqueria.  I want very simple burritos & some consideration for my vegetarian ways.  I used to be a fan of Chino's because they're fairly nearby and they don't suck, but Chino's has let me down.  They have the carne assata (I don't know how to spell it, I'm vegetarian!) bin just past the rice bin & they use a slotted spoon to scoop the meat.  Last time I was there, I was horrified to watch them DUMP meat juice all over their rice, then make me a burrito with it.  No no no, I will not go back.  Too bad, I liked them.

Bits from my old review, for the omnivores out there: It's affordable ($8.45 or so for 2 big burritos and chips), they are very nice, they have different kinds of tortillas, their horchata is decent...I can't think of what else I could want.  500 times better than nasty Gordo's!
author: Ljótur H.

description:
My bf and I live 3 blocks down and boy do we love this place.  The owners are great people, who load you up with the essential goodies (guac, sour cream, meat of choice etc.).  This place is a small hole in the wall, with a quiant seating area.  It's so popular, that sometimes the line streams out the door.

My fav's on the menu: Carne Asada super burrito with Spinach Tortilla, Carnitas Tacos and Super Nachos.
author: Anne K.

description: Not very good. The super burrito with spicy chicken was not spicy, was not super, and was not memorable. I forgot what everything tasted like moments after finishing it. This is a good place for a cheap bite to eat that will fill you up, and do little else.
author: Kevin A.

description: I've had many burritos growing up in the Mission, faves being Taqueria Cancun and Pancho Villa.  I wasn't sure about this place in the Richmond..but we were all starving, close to this place and figured why not.  Got a Super veggie burrito with black beans on a spinach tortilla and it was actually pretty good. I'd give it a 4 out of 5. The flavors were mild but all fresh. I'd try it again and request some spicy additions next time.
author: Lucky P.

description:
It is hard to rate Chinos - it gets two stars only because it is in the outer Richmond district.  Otherwise it would get one star.  There just aren't good burritos out by the beach on the north side of town.

Good things: Cheap, fairly friendly, and close by.  

Good cheap veggie burrito - don't bother with the Guacamole (just OK), cheese (cheap) or sour cream (bland) because they are all kinda crappy.  

Do NOT get the pickled jalapenos on your burrito they are very acidic - and give me heart burn - this is the only place I have every gotten heart burn!  Ever!

I never really cared for any of the other burritos.  The Quesadillas are well liked by kids.

Only go if you live in the neighborhood.
author: jeff b.

description:
2.5 stars for Chinos.

When I lived in The Richmond I went to Chinos at least once a week.  I'm a creature of habit and would usually order the same thing.  The food was tasty enough so I kept going back, but I hold a grudge against them because despite being a regular patron, they were never friendly or welcoming.

I didn't aspire to be the "Norm from Cheers" of Chinos, but it puzzled me that everytime I walked through the door it was like they'd never waited on me before.  I had to specify what toppings I wanted, despite my ordering pretty much the same thing everytime.  And you had to pay extra for chips.

If I still lived out there I'd probably still frequent them and grumble under my breath about the service.  

signed,

Nobody knew my name
author: Landy G.

description:
I wanted to like this place because they're my closest local burrito joint and want to support small business owners, blah, blah, but their food is just TERRIBLE.  Amnesia about bad food can be a freind and foe as I had forgotten how bad it was 7 years ago and decided it was time for another try.  

Two burritos, the carnitas and the spicy pork.  I honestly wanted to run out of the place when I saw the array of food in the hot trays, as the lettuce looked a weird color and the meats looked completely underwhelming.  My friend and I shared and both burritos were terrible to the point of incompletion.  Lettuce not only looked weird but tasted pickled or something, which was just gross.  Tomatoes underripe and salsa did nothing to help or hide matters.  Rice was funky and meat was bland.    

I try not to be but may be a burrito snob since we have the best of the best in the Bay Area but you know what?  Terrible and inedible are just that and transcend snobbery.  

The folks who work there seem but too bad niceness does not translate into good or even passable food.  

Avoid at all costs.
author: Annabelle J.

description:
Just picked up 2 chicken super burritos on spinach wrap. Delicious!!!
Heard about this place for years and finally I know what the talk is about. Chicken, black beans, rice, chopped tomato salsa,sour cream,guacamole,Mexican cheese, hot sauce,chopped onion/veg topping,spinach wrap. I'M STUFFED! Get 2 to go. You'll be happy.
author: Martha N.

description: Great food, nice guys, and very consistent. This is our usual burrito place and we've even branched out to their nachos, tacos, quesadillas and the Chino's Plate. All of it is great and they aren't skimpy on the portions.
author: Amy C.

description: Chinos chinos chinos.  They used to be great.  I used to love them so much more than any other taqueria, and certainly more than Gordo's.  But I can't say that anymore.  These days, I'd rather have a Gordo's taqueria than a Chino's one, and that's pretty sad since Chino's is only two blocks from my house and Gordo's is a car ride.  Their burritos have gotten much smaller, they're pretty cheap with the ingredients over the last few years.  And not only that, the prices have gone up!  I'll go here in a pinch, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here anymore.  Sad!
author: Maureen L.

description:
I love this place so much that once I went there at 10:30 in the morning -- which is right when they open -- and ordered a huge-ass veggie burrito with everything on it -- cheese, rice, pinto beans, gobs of guacamole, loads of sour cream, green sauce, jalapenos, etc..

And ate the whole thing right there and then.

Hell yes.
author: Michaela B.

description: Been eating here since high school days at Wash.. I still live near by so i guess you can say Chino's is my neighborhood taqueria.. but, it's the BEST, better than Gordos.. Choose what color tortilla u like.. shredded cheese.. and i usually go w carnidas, although i used to go w the spicy chicken, which you can't get at Gordos either.. hah   (but after reading Steph D's review, i might hav to stick w carnidas..)  1 minus star cause a meter maid gave me a ticket out front
author: scott T.

description:
anyone who likes this place has obviously never had real mexican food. 

its too expensive for the quality, dont even get me started on the quantity. its the cheapest quality, and they STILL put barely anything in your burritos. 


just dont do it. theres plenty of really good asian restaurants in the area.
author: alana v.

description: We are from Fla but come to SF a few times a year and Chino's is a must every time. The people are super nice, the place is unpretentious and the spicy chicken ROCKS! I don't even eat chicken---but I do at Chino's!!  We have eaten at 6 or 7 taquerias in the Mission and none can compare! Plus, the Richmond is also a great neighborhood to walk around--the beach, the park, Land's End---amazing. I wish we could afford to live there, but are happy with our few trips a year.
author: Kelley H.

description:
I like good mexican food.I mean,I admit I get home in the wee hours during the weekends and want  something from this place,but they are closed.

Chino's is a good small place you wouldn't expect to be "great",but they are.

A good place to go when you are on the go or want a quckie.

Not the quickie you think I mean.
author: Mattee M.

description:
Food is pretty standard for a taqueria.  Prices are more than you would get in the Mission and the chips aren't free.

One bathroom for everyone, which sometimes requires a key.
author: Huy Z.

description: I thought this place was good until I saw the server pull out a long black hair from the sour cream... After I saw that I wonder what else I didn't catch, CHINOS = DIRTY.
author: Joshua L.

description: I LOVE this place. The employees are very friendly and you can even have a conversation with them. The Taqueria has a very authentic vibe, and is great after a day at Ocean beach when all I want in this world is one of their grilled chicken burritos and a cold drink. The aspect of Chino's that I admire, besides the very friendly service, is the high quality of the meat. I hate it when I get a disgusting chewy tendon or other gross things in meat, but i have never gotten that from Chino's. I've been coming here since forever and i highly recommend the grilled chicken, but every meat they serve is flavorful enough to be eaten plain. The homemade chips they sell for 50 cents a bag are also great. I truly think this is the best Taqueria in the city and Bay Area.
author: Sarah G.

description: Pretty bad... Went there for lunch and it was empty. The reason became clear to me a couple bites into my taco. My mother in law got sick after a chicken burrito as well. I've got ONE word for anyone in the Richmond looking for Taqueria food... GORDO'S!!
author: Natas N.

description: Gotta craving for a Super burrito? Stop by Chino's and get yourself something that's about the size of a Thermal coffee cup. Yes their super burritos are that big. It'll fill you up and leave you sleepy like after Thanksgiving dinner... well.. without all your extended family. Line up and tell the guy what you want and bammo you got yourself a burrito the size of a grande coffee cup at Starbucks. Go figure it costs about the same as a grande cup. In any case, it's a great place to pick up food. Good bang for your recession/depression buck.
author: Allan T.

description: Chino's is about 6 blocks away from our home. I've been bringing my kids here for 10 years (my youngest, when she was a baby, would gnaw on their pinto beans and rice). Anyhow, a favorite spot for my kids and I for a quick bite to eat on a busy school night. My kids like the green burritos; I usually go for a grilled chicken quesadilla or super burrito. Occasionally, we'll go for their nachos. Good food, good guacamole. As other reviewers point out, not the fanciest place around; the bathrooms have a fair amount of graffiti and the like. But, a great, unassuming spot to grab a quick burrito.
author: Ben E.

description:
This place has people lined up out the door most evenings and parking in my drive way. That said they do a real nice job. The food is fresh and I know they spend a lot of time preparing stuff in the morning because when I leave around 6am somebody's there and getting stuff ready. 

A solid product at a good price.
author: Brian B.

description:
Solid burrito. I had the Carnitas, light sour cream. Black beans. Came standard with cheese and guac, although guac was thin. 

Cash only and reasonably priced. It was 5.50 before taxes or extras.

Three stars for a solid burrito that I would probably get again, the convenience of it to my house is amazing, about three blocks. It wasn't the best burrito in the city, I don't even think Ive had that yet...any suggestions?

Good, not great. But not bad by any means, a solid 3/5
author: Kevin R.

description: Hells, bells, and Chino's taco shells.  This place is worth the 3 hours I spend on the toilet afterwards.
author: Ellen R.

description: I love the quesadillas here! I am vegetarian and manage to get a fantastic one with guacamole, sour cream, rice, black beans, and salsa. Yes, they grill it on the same grill as everything else, but I am not that picky. The dudes that work there are always cool, too.
author: Chris S.

description:
